thothbot.parallax.core.shared.cameras

Class PerspectiveCamera

  • java.lang.Object
    • thothbot.parallax.core.shared.core.Object3D
      • thothbot.parallax.core.shared.cameras.Camera
        • thothbot.parallax.core.shared.cameras.PerspectiveCamera
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    com.google.gwt.event.shared.EventHandler, HasEventBus, ViewportResizeHandler, HasNearFar

    public class PerspectiveCamera
extends Camera
implements HasNearFar
    Camera with perspective projection. 
     
 PerspectiveCamera camera = new PerspectiveCamera( 45, width / height, 1, 1000 );
    Author:
    thothbot

      • zoom

        public double zoom

    • Constructor Detail

      • PerspectiveCamera

        public PerspectiveCamera()
        Perspective Camera default constructor. It uses the following defaults:
        • fieldOfView - 50
        • aspectRatio - 1
        • near - 0.1
        • far - 2000

      • PerspectiveCamera

        public PerspectiveCamera(double fieldOfView,
                         double aspectRatio,
                         double near,
                         double far)
        Perspective Camera constructor
        Parameters:
        fieldOfView - Camera frustum vertical field of view.
        aspectRatio - Camera frustum aspect ratio.
        near - Camera frustum near plane.
        far - Camera frustum far plane.

      • setLens

        public void setLens(int focalLength,
                    int frameHeight)
        Uses Focal Length (in mm) to estimate and set FOV 35mm (fullframe) camera is used if frame size is not specified.
        Formula based on bobatkins.com
        Parameters:
        focalLength - the focal length
        frameHeight - the frame size

      • setViewOffset

        public void setViewOffset(int fullWidth,
                          int fullHeight,
                          double x,
                          double y,
                          int width,
                          int height)
        Sets an offset in a larger frustum. This is useful for multi-window or multi-monitor/multi-machine setups.

        For example, if you have 3x2 monitors and each monitor is 1920x1080 and the monitors are in grid like this 

        

   +---+---+---+
   | A | B | C |
   +---+---+---+
   | D | E | F |
   +---+---+---+
        then for each monitor you would call it like this 
        

   double w = 1920;
   double h = 1080;
   double fullWidth = w * 3;
   double fullHeight = h * 2;

   --A--
   camera.setOffset( fullWidth, fullHeight, w * 0, h * 0, w, h );
   --B--
   camera.setOffset( fullWidth, fullHeight, w * 1, h * 0, w, h );
   --C--
   camera.setOffset( fullWidth, fullHeight, w * 2, h * 0, w, h );
   --D--
   camera.setOffset( fullWidth, fullHeight, w * 0, h * 1, w, h );
   --E--
   camera.setOffset( fullWidth, fullHeight, w * 1, h * 1, w, h );
   --F--
   camera.setOffset( fullWidth, fullHeight, w * 2, h * 1, w, h );
        Note there is no reason monitors have to be the same size or in a grid.
        Parameters:
        fullWidth - the full width of multiview setup
        fullHeight - the full height of multiview setup
        x - the horizontal offset of subcamera
        y - the vertical offset of subcamera
        width - the width of subcamera
        height - the height of subcamera

      • updateProjectionMatrix

        public void updateProjectionMatrix()
        Updates the camera projection matrix.

        Must be called after change of parameters.
